ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about continuities and discontinuities in Jewish political history. This course offered a lot of insightful vocabulary and terms with which to refer to certain phenomena and strategies in Jewish politics.
This is one of those history classes that teaches you how to approach history. I learned how to look at issues in new ways and approach trends and tensions with a fresh perspective.

I learned how to analyze Jewish political history both separately and in conjunction with general history, as well as comparing and analyzing Jewish political history across times and places. I also learned how to construct a better historical argument, especially with regard to sourcing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Only strengths  the course is wonderfully structured. The reading can be a bit heavy but its really worth it to do it as often/as fully as possible.

Strengths--love Prof Sorkin, great TFs, great content
No weaknesses

Strengths: The material was gripping; Prof Sorkin organized the themes, contexts, and matching texts and sources in an extremely accessible and useful way. I thoroughly enjoyed the work I did in this course, especially, reading, discussing, and writing. 

Weaknesses: Prof. Sorkin teaches this like a graduate course, which is part of what makes it so great, but that can prove challenging, especially with regards to 1. assumed prior knowledge and 2. the number and length of texts we were expected to read each week. It was acknowledged and understood that we weren't supposed to actually get every word from every text, but I think it could have been better if Prof. Sorkin notified us in advance of what texts or sources or chapters were most crucial to read and understand.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: What an amazing class. Professor Sorkin is one of the best professors I've ever had at Yale. The class was leminar-style, and my favorite part was always getting to hear him lecture - he is so knowledgeable and patient and breaks down complicated histories in such an easy-to-understand way. More than any class I've taken, the course was truly well-organized in terms of thematics, and we looked at a few things at the beginning of the course that we continued to evaluate in every subsequent unit - it was great, and surely made me a better history student. You get to write and then re-write each paper after feedback which is such a great way to become a better writer, and also makes everything a lot less stressful. Amazing class, highly recommend.
lots and lots of reading, take it if you're very interested in the topics covered
Absolutely. Even if you have no connection to Judaism, this course is such a fantastic history course that is easy to fall in love with.

YES -- good amount of reading and writing, but it's manageable and enjoyable. If you're at all curious about the topic and want to read the stories of those involved in different Jewish political movements and changes in Jewish life during the 20th century, please take this class.
Definitely. Both Prof and TF are incredible and deserve teaching awards. If you like Jewish history or political science this is a course for you.
